title: Wish You Were Here [Jodi Picoult]
descriptions:
Title: Wish You Were Here [Jodi Picoult]

Description: Wish You Were Here is a powerful and thought-provoking novel that explores the devastating impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on individuals and society as a whole. Jodi Picoult's extensive research is evident throughout the book, offering readers a deep and visceral understanding of the trauma, grief, and resilience experienced by people during this challenging time.

The story follows Diana O'Toole, an ambitious art specialist at Sotheby's, and her boyfriend Finn, a surgical resident in New York City. They have meticulously planned a dream trip to the Galapagos Islands, but their plans are shattered when Finn is called to the frontlines of the pandemic. Determined to make the most of her vacation, Diana decides to go alone, unaware of the chaos and isolation that awaits her.

Picoult skillfully portrays Diana's journey of self-discovery as she navigates the challenges of being stranded on the island. The author delves into themes of identity, love, and the choices we make in life. The character development is superb, with Diana's transformation and her relationships with the locals, particularly Gabriel and his daughter Beatriz, adding depth and emotional resonance to the narrative.

The book takes an unexpected turn with a jaw-dropping revelation that will leave readers reeling. It is a testament to Picoult's storytelling prowess that she manages to keep readers engaged and surprised throughout the narrative. The emotional impact of the story is heightened by the author's poignant and honest depiction of the medical professionals on the frontlines of the pandemic, highlighting their bravery and sacrifice.

While the first half of the book may feel slow to some readers, the payoff in the second half is well worth the wait. The exploration of the pandemic's impact on individuals' lives and the subsequent reevaluation of priorities and values is timely and thought-provoking. It forces readers to reflect on their own lives and choices, making this book a compelling and relevant read.

Wish You Were Here is a beautifully written novel that captures the raw emotions and complexities of the COVID-19 pandemic. It is a testament to the resilience of the human spirit and the power of love and connection in times of crisis. Jodi Picoult's meticulous research, compelling storytelling, and heartfelt ending make this book a standout in her body of work. Highly recommended for readers who appreciate introspective and emotionally charged narratives.

I would like to extend my gratitude to NetGalley and Random House Publishing Group / Ballantine Books for providing me with an advanced copy of this book in exchange for an honest review.

Title: Wish You Were Here [Jodi Picoult]

Description: Wish You Were Here by Jodi Picoult is a powerful and timely novel that delves into the depths of the COVID-19 pandemic. Picoult's extensive research shines through, providing readers with an authentic and visceral portrayal of the trauma and devastation caused by the virus.

The story follows Diana O'Toole, an art specialist at Sotheby's, who had meticulously planned a dream vacation to the Galapagos Islands with her boyfriend Finn. However, when the pandemic hits and Finn is called to the frontlines as a surgical resident, Diana decides to embark on the trip alone. Little does she know that she will become trapped on the island due to travel restrictions and lockdowns.

Picoult expertly captures the sense of isolation and loneliness that Diana experiences. As she navigates the challenges of being stranded in a foreign land without her luggage and limited communication, readers are taken on a journey of self-reflection and personal growth. Through her interactions with the locals, particularly Gabriel and his daughter Beatriz, Diana begins to question her preconceived notions and reevaluate her life choices.

The novel takes an unexpected turn with a jaw-dropping twist that I won't spoil. It adds another layer of complexity to the story and forces readers to examine their own beliefs and assumptions. While there were moments when I found Diana's character frustrating and selfish, her journey of self-discovery is undeniably compelling.

Picoult's writing is impeccable, and the pacing of the story keeps readers engaged throughout. The author's attention to detail and vivid descriptions transport readers to the Galapagos Islands, making it feel like a character in itself. The emotional depth and thought-provoking themes explored in Wish You Were Here make it a perfect choice for book club discussions.

Overall, Wish You Were Here is a poignant and thought-provoking novel that will resonate with readers long after they turn the final page. It serves as a reminder of the profound impact of the pandemic and the importance of reevaluating our priorities in life. Jodi Picoult's storytelling prowess is on full display in this remarkable work. I highly recommend it.

I would like to express my gratitude to NetGalley and Random House Publishing Group / Ballantine Books for providing me with an advanced reader copy in exchange for an honest review.

Title: Wish You Were Here [Jodi Picoult]

Description: Wish You Were Here by Jodi Picoult is a thought-provoking and emotionally impactful novel that delves into the complexities of human lives during the COVID-19 pandemic. The author's extensive research on the virus shines through, providing readers with a realistic and chilling portrayal of the traumatic experiences faced by frontline medical professionals. 

The story follows Diana O'Toole, an art specialist at Sotheby's, whose meticulously planned life takes an unexpected turn when her boyfriend Finn, a surgical resident, is unable to join her on their dream trip to the Galapagos due to the outbreak of COVID-19. Stranded on the island, Diana is faced with numerous challenges, from language barriers to a lack of basic amenities. However, her encounters with a local family and a mysterious man open her eyes to a new perspective on life.

While the first half of the book may feel slow at times, it sets the stage for the surprising twists and turns that lie ahead. The author's ability to craft multi-layered characters adds depth to the narrative, allowing readers to connect with the story on a profound level. 

Picoult's writing is engaging and evocative, capturing the essence of the Galapagos Islands and the beauty of its natural surroundings. The novel also explores themes of forgiveness, resilience, and self-discovery, prompting readers to reflect on their own choices and priorities in life.

Overall, Wish You Were Here is a compelling and insightful novel that offers a unique perspective on the COVID-19 pandemic. It may not be suitable for all readers, particularly those who are not ready to revisit the traumas of the past year. However, for those who are willing to delve into its pages, this book provides a captivating and thought-provoking reading experience. Highly recommended for book clubs, as it offers plenty of material for discussion.

I would like to express my gratitude to NetGalley and Random House Publishing Group / Ballantine Books for providing me with an advanced copy of this book in exchange for an honest review.

Title: Wish You Were Here [Jodi Picoult]

Description: Wish You Were Here by Jodi Picoult is a thought-provoking and emotionally poignant novel that delves into the complexities of human life during the COVID-19 pandemic. The author's extensive research on the virus is evident, providing readers with a visceral understanding of the trauma and hardships faced by individuals around the world. While this book may not be suitable for everyone at this time, it offers a compelling narrative that explores themes of love, resilience, bravery, and hope in the face of a global crisis.

The story follows Diana O'Toole, an art acquisition specialist at Sotheby's, who has meticulously planned her future with her boyfriend, Finn. However, when Finn is unable to accompany her on their dream trip to the Galapagos due to the pandemic, Diana finds herself alone on the island. As she navigates the challenges of being stranded in a foreign place, she forms unexpected connections with the locals, particularly Gabriel and his daughter, Beatriz.

Picoult's writing is captivating and multi-layered, with well-developed characters that feel authentic. The novel takes a surprising turn, which I won't reveal to avoid spoilers, but it adds depth and complexity to the story. While I did find the first half of the book slow-paced, the latter half more than makes up for it with its insightful exploration of life choices and the importance of reevaluating what truly matters.

One aspect that stood out to me was Picoult's portrayal of the frontline medical staff and their heroic efforts to combat the virus. The book provides a dark, honest depiction of their experiences, reminding readers of the immense respect and gratitude we owe to these frontline heroes.

Wish You Were Here is a book that will stay with readers long after they finish it. It offers a unique perspective on the pandemic and prompts us to reflect on our own lives and the choices we make. While there were elements of the story that I didn't personally connect with, I appreciate the author's ability to tackle such a timely and sensitive topic with grace and depth.

I would highly recommend this book to those who are ready to delve into a thought-provoking narrative that explores the human condition during a global crisis. It would make an excellent choice for book clubs, as it invites deep discussion and introspection. Many thanks to NetGalley and Random House Publishing Group / Ballantine Books for providing me with an ARC in exchange for my honest review.

Title: Wish You Were Here [Jodi Picoult]

Description: Wish You Were Here by Jodi Picoult is a thought-provoking and emotionally charged novel that delves into the complexities of life during the COVID-19 pandemic. The author's extensive research is evident, providing a raw and realistic portrayal of the trauma, heartbreak, and resilience experienced by individuals worldwide.

The story follows Diana O'Toole, an art specialist at Sotheby's, who plans a dream vacation to the Galapagos Islands with her boyfriend, Finn. However, when Finn is called to the front lines of the pandemic, Diana finds herself alone on the island, cut off from the world. As she navigates the challenges of being stranded in an unfamiliar place with limited resources, she forms unexpected connections with the locals and begins to question her own life choices.

Picoult's storytelling is masterful, capturing the essence of human emotions and the impact of global events on individuals. The narrative takes an unexpected turn, leaving readers on the edge of their seats and challenging their preconceived notions. The author skillfully weaves together themes of love, loss, identity, and forgiveness, creating a multi-layered and thought-provoking reading experience.

While the first half of the book may seem slow-paced, it sets the stage for the emotional journey that unfolds in the latter half. The character development is exceptional, with Diana's flaws and growth making her relatable and authentic. The exploration of the pandemic's effects on relationships and personal growth is timely and poignant.

One particular highlight is the author's portrayal of the medical professionals on the front lines, showcasing their dedication, bravery, and sacrifices. It serves as a reminder of the heroes who have tirelessly fought against the virus and kept hope alive during these challenging times.

Wish You Were Here is not a light read, as it delves deep into the realities of the pandemic. It demands patience from readers, but the payoff is worth it. The book leaves a lasting impact, encouraging introspection and reflection on what truly matters in life.

Overall, Jodi Picoult's Wish You Were Here is a poignant and insightful novel that captures the essence of the COVID-19 pandemic. It is a testament to the author's storytelling prowess and her ability to tackle complex themes with grace. Highly recommended for those seeking a thought-provoking and emotionally charged read.

I would like to express my gratitude to NetGalley and Random House Publishing Group/Ballantine Books for providing me with an advanced review copy in exchange for my honest feedback.

Title: Wish You Were Here [Jodi Picoult]

Description: Wish You Were Here by Jodi Picoult is a powerful and timely novel that delves into the complex emotions and challenges faced during the COVID-19 pandemic. The story follows Diana O'Toole, an art specialist at Sotheby's, as she embarks on a planned vacation to the Galapagos Islands without her boyfriend, Finn, who is a surgical resident. However, as the pandemic intensifies, Diana finds herself trapped on the island, facing numerous obstacles and forced to reevaluate her life choices.

Picoult's research into the realities of the pandemic is evident throughout the book. She provides a raw and honest portrayal of the trauma and devastation caused by COVID-19, particularly through Finn's emails detailing the experiences of frontline medical professionals. This novel serves as a reminder of the heroic efforts made by healthcare workers and the importance of their work.

The first half of the book may feel slow to some readers, as Diana navigates the challenges of being alone on the island and struggles to communicate with Finn. However, the story takes a surprising twist that will leave readers stunned. Without revealing too much, I can say that the twist adds depth and complexity to the narrative, making it a worthwhile read.

Picoult's writing is engaging and skillful, with well-developed characters and a thought-provoking exploration of themes such as parental abandonment and the importance of reevaluating one's priorities. The emotional journey of the protagonist, Diana, is relatable and compelling, and readers will find themselves questioning their own choices and priorities.

While there are some flaws in the book, such as moments when Diana's actions may be seen as selfish, overall, Wish You Were Here is a poignant and insightful novel. It offers a unique perspective on the pandemic and prompts readers to reflect on their own lives and values.

I recommend this book to those who are ready to confront the realities of the COVID-19 pandemic and are interested in exploring the profound impact it has had on individuals. Wish You Were Here is a thought-provoking and emotionally resonant read that will leave a lasting impression.
generation_prompt_text:
Read the following reviews of a certain book and write a review of your own for the same book, as if you are a reader who cares about writing quality book reviews. Use a similar level of quality to the given reviews. Try to include only information that was present in the given reviews, and do not invent new information about the book.

---

Title: Wish You Were Here [Jodi Picoult]

Description: This book took my breath away, making me terrified, scared, shaking me to the core: I’m overwhelmed because of dealing with complex feelings at the same time: sadness, amusement, excitement, stress, worry,anxiousness…

It’s another Sliding Doors theme: where you could be and what kind of situations you may deal with if you make different choices about your life in the middle of pandemic.

This is philosophical, metal psychical and psychological novel about how human lives evolve, how they change, how adapt in new normal but mostly it’s about how to stay alive and protect our sanity when all hell breaks loose?

Diane O’Toole, associate assistant at Sotheby’s, living with her surgical resident boyfriend Finn in NYC, mapped out her entire life with him: the house they live, the children they have, the bucket list trips they go, the retirement plans etc.

Nearly four years they saved up for Galapagos trip they planned: this is the best time for Diane because legendary Kitomi Ito ( quiet twin of Yoko Ono) decided to postpone the auction of the famous Toulouse - Lautrec painting she owned because of uprising of contagious virus. This auction of masterpiece could bring the promotion to Diane, she’s working so hard for.

But she is still keeping her hopes up: because she found a ring is hidden inside Finn’s socks. This means he’s planning to propose on their vacation and she’s going to say: yes! She’s gonna celebrate her 30th birthday as an engaged woman.

Well, when they made plans, God laughed and eventually Finn admits: it’s all hands on deck at the hospital: the COVID cases start to hit NYC faster than they imagine. So he offers her to go alone and interestingly she accepts!

But as soon as she gets off the plane she realizes her baggage is missing and that’s not the only predicament she has to face. When she gets off the ferry to walk to her hotel, she realizes her hotel is closed and for two weeks the entire island is shut down for quarantine.

Thankfully a local woman provides her a house to stay, leaving traditional food at her kitchen. But Diane gets herself trapped in an island without knowing the langue islanders talk, failing to obey the curfew times, dealing with the hostile manners of a mysterious, charismatic man and her cash is about to run out at this place which doesn’t have any ATM machines. Did I also tell you there’s no proper internet connection! She starts writing postcards to communicate with Finn but the post office is also close. How will she send them?

But her fate crosses with this charismatic mysterious man and his daughter which probably change her entire vision and perspective about the island!

I’m not giving more spoilers! But i can only say that in the middle of the book, I dropped my e-reader and I screamed WTH!

After shocking, jaw dropping revelation later, thankfully we didn’t have a bumpy ride. The emotional approach of the story and fair- satisfying ending made me smile a lot. I think I can give 10 stars for the heartfelt, earth shattering ending! It’s like last epic scene of remarkable movie!

This book realistically tells us the terrifying and ugly face of COVID- 19. Especially Finn’s emails draw dark, compelling, horrifying and also honest depictions about how the entire medical professionals are fighting against the lethal disease. It makes you remind of respecting them so deeply! They are the real heroes who saved our lives and gave us hope to hold on for so long!

Jodi Picoult is amazing storyteller: reflecting the dark face of tragedy we’ve been confronting nearly 1 and half years. She also depicted the perfect pictures of Galapagos. She told us a story of a girl who planned everything to choose different path from her mother she resented for abandoning her. But she also told how to open our hearts and forgive each other to be free from our resentments.

I extremely loved this book so much ! I think this is one of the best works of the author. I liked Dante ( Tenth Circle is her another book focused on Dante’s Inferno), Tiger King ( I agree she is guilty), Charles Darwin’s Theory of Evolution by natural selection references!

This is one of the books you want to reread at different parts and timelines of your life. Annie’s inner journey will stay in your mind forever and eventually it will encourage you to start your inner journey to find out what you want to do with one and precious life of yours!

Special thanks to NetGalley and Random House Publishing Group / Ballantine Books for sharing this digital reviewer copy with me in exchange my honest opinions.

---

Title: Wish You Were Here [Jodi Picoult]

Description: Of all the books I have read this year, I cannot think of any that will resonate so deeply with a global audience as this one. Jodi Picoult carries out an impressive level of research for her oh so human look at the pain, losses, lockdown, heartbreak, grief, loneliness and isolation experienced by people as the horrifying nightmare of Covid-19 took hold and shut down so much of the world. I can understand if this is too soon for many readers to read about, but I found this to be an absolutely riveting read, highlighting the incredibly courageous work of the frontline medical staff, whilst providing an insightful glimpse into the beauty and nature of the Galapagos Islands, its people, history and culture.

In New York, the ambitious Diana O'Toole is almost thirty, and on the verge of achieving all that she wants professionally as an art specialist at Sotheby's, and personally, convinced that Finn Colson, a surgical resident at the Presbyterian hospital will propose on a trip to Galapagos to celebrate her 30th birthday. However, her carefully planned life is about to be shot into tiny pieces when Finn is unable to go with her as a medical emergency develops with the beginnings of the Covid-19 virus. Diana arrives on Galapagos as it is going into quarantine and lockdown, leaving her stranded, her luggage is lost, she cannot speak the language, and communications are patchy. She is isolated and lonely, but finds herself connecting with a local family. Like so many people, Diana is to find herself re-evaluating her sense of identity and working out what really matters in life.

There is a humdinger of a ingenious twist that Picoult weaves into the narrative that I cannot reveal as it will be entering into spoiler territory. This is one of the author's best works, it is multi-layered, the characters are stellar and feel so authentic, and whilst it does not make for easy reading, I found myself turning the pages as fast as I could. Ultimately, this is a emotionally poignant, thought provoking novel, of what it is to be human, and the love, resilence, bravery and hope in the face of a global pandemic that broke so many lives. I think so many readers will love and appreciate this book. Highly recommended. Many thanks to the publisher for an ARC.

---

Title: Wish You Were Here [Jodi Picoult]

Description: Hmm, this is a tough one to review.

In the end, I liked what Jodi Picoult did with Wish You Were Here. I like that she took it in, let's say, unexpected directions, and explored a subject I knew very little about. I did not predict the way this story would unfold. Which is good.

That being said, I found the first half of this book very slow. Diana finds herself alone in the Galápagos islands, her boyfriend thousands of miles away fighting to save people from COVID in the emergency room, when the island is put on lockdown. With no way to get home, Diana wanders around being a bit of an ignorant tourist, meeting the locals, and trying to find a way to feed herself.

Diana becomes involved in the lives of local businessman, Gabriel, and his daughter, Beatriz. Through these new friendships and interactions, she begins to question what she had thought she wanted from her life, to question the path she is on and whether it is the right one. This goes on for more than half of the book (192 pages in the e-arc). I was not enamoured by it.

As I said earlier, though, the book does go on to take some interesting turns. It's unfortunate that what I liked about the book would reveal too much, so I can only really talk about my complaints here.

It's rewarding for the patient reader.

---

Title: Wish You Were Here [Jodi Picoult]

Description: 4.5 stars
Wow, I'm not sure how to put into words what I just read.

I will start off with a bit of a warning. If you're not in a place where you can read about the experiences of Covid from many different angles, then I'd recommend you steer clear of this one for a while. The trauma of the pandemic is very real, and the author does an incredibly good job of conveying it to the reader in a visceral way.

I have not read a book by Picoult in years. I became disenchanted with her issues-driven writing that always felt like it had an agenda. I suppose this one is similar, but it doesn't seem to be forcing things down my throat. I had seen so many stellar reviews for it that I took the chance to pick this one up and wasn't disappointed.

It takes a LOT to surprise me. I maybe read one or two books a year that truly knock me off kilter with a surprise. This one might be my one for the year.

This book features Diana, an art acquisition specialist at Sotheby's with a long term boyfriend, Finn, who is a surgical resident. The two are planning a bucket list trip to the Galapagos in March of 2020, and Diana found an engagement ring hidden in the dresser so she is pretty sure Finn will propose during the trip. Yet Covid has begun to hit New York City with a vengeance, and Finn has to stay and work, it is all hands on deck. He encourages Diana to go on the trip without him and she reluctantly agrees. As soon as she arrives on the small island, the world goes into lockdown and she's unable to return home. Communication is spotty. She gradually gets to know some of the residents of the island, and becomes very close to them.

The book is so much more complex than my short synopsis can convey. There are parental abandonment issues, re-examination of life choices, and myriad other issues that the pandemic brought to the surface for many, if not all of us. The reason I didn't rate this a full five stars was because I didn't really like Diana most of the time (sometimes she is sympathetic, but other times she is very selfish) and I hate infidelity in any form. I get that she was struggling being so isolated and far away, but to me it isn't an excuse and so a half of a star taken away for that.

However this book overall is incredibly insightful and thought provoking, as well has having a jaw dropping moment that I won't forget anytime soon. If anything, this book should make everyone really think about the choices we make in life and why we are making those choices. The pandemic has allowed many of us to reassess what is truly important in our lives. This is a meaty book, filled with emotion and anguish, and like I said at the beginning, it's not a book for everyone at this time. I really appreciated the author's note at the end and it gave me so much perspective about the choices that the author made in her writing of this novel.

This would make a fantastic book club choice, there's a lot here that begs to be discussed and dissected.

Edited to add: I think she missed a golden opportunity to add an Easter egg here and call the singing group the Scarabs or something beetle related rather than bird related.

I voluntarily reviewed a complimentary copy of this book, all opinions are my own.

---

Title: Wish You Were Here [Jodi Picoult]

Description: Diana O’Toole, an associate specialist for Sotheby’s auction house, has her perfect life in NYC with surgical resident, Finn, mapped out - all that’s missing is the proposal and wedding, and she’s pretty sure she’s about to get the former on their romantic vacation to the Galapagos. When the initial wave of COVID hits and Finn is needed at the hospital, Diana goes solo and finds herself trapped longer than expected by travel restrictions. What she discovers during and after this extended vacation opens her eyes and makes her re-evaluate the future she’s envisioned.

I’ve learned something about myself after finishing this book:

I think I’m broken. Looking around at all my friends’ glowing reviews for this, I have to wonder why I didn’t feel those things too.

Let me start with some things Jodi Picoult did so well in this book, though, because she deserves credit where it’s due:

First: This woman researched the hell out of the major aspects of COVID-19 from transmission to its after effects and it SHOWS. Many won’t be ready for such an unflinching, no-holds-barred look at this virus, but if you ever feel ready to look at it more closely in the relative safety of a fictionalized story, this is your book. It’s difficult and sobering at times, but it’s also terribly insightful and honest, and I can respect that. I learned a lot that I didn’t know, and I think it’s a tremendous learning opportunity for those who want it.

Second: She writes very well. Structure, plot, fully-developed characters, pacing, atmosphere, the big twist, which was so clever … it’s all there. It’s perfectly good fiction, and it will appeal to many readers, as evidenced by all those aforementioned glowing reviews.

So why didn’t it work as well for me?

First: The story felt forced. COVID-19 was really the body of the book, so to speak, and Diana’s story was just the clothing thrown on to disguise it. Picoult had all this knowledge about the virus to share, but it felt much better suited for a non-fiction book. Finn’s emails to Diana were just woefully unrealistic to me. Not the detailed names of medicines, machines and interventions used on patients - that was highly factual, but given their circumstances of being separated for so long, it didn’t feel like this is what he’d be spending all his time writing the love of his life about.

Second: Despite the reasoning for Diana’s decision-making and conclusions, I couldn’t get onboard with it. I can’t really discuss it for spoiler reasons, but it didn’t ring true to me, and I really didn't like the ending. She just didn't make sense to me.

Third: The first half of the book was - there’s no way to put this politely - kind of boring. Maybe that was intentional on the author’s part to put the reader back in the mindset of the early days of the pandemic when everything was shut down and we were spending our days struggling to find things to do, but this reader wasn’t ready to revisit those days and how the world felt then.

As I said, it’s a well-written book with an abundance of 4 and 5-star reviews, so I encourage you to read some of those before deciding whether the book is for you. It’s simply a case of right book, wrong reader for me.

★★★ ½

Thanks to Random House Publishing Group - Ballantine, NetGalley and author Jodi Picoult for this ARC in exchange for my honest opinions. It’s due for publication on November 30, 2021.

This review and all my others can also be seen at: https://acuriouskatreads.blogspot.com/
